segments.text: The desires of the wife.
When I said, sure, I'd like to be chief of staff.
And he said, well, you better talk it over with Mimi.
I said, well, I will.
And he said, better than that.
I said, I'm going to talk to her.
So he called her, and she said, oh, yes, we'd be delighted to do this.
But I sure would like to live across the street.
But we were an island type of thing.
Across the street, you have privacy, a backyard up against us.
had a big high fence, and it was a German field in the back.
And for the price, he said, sure, no problem at all.
But he called up to get permission.
They said, absolutely not.
He said, but he'll move at his own expense.
I said, we don't care.
In principle, we're not making any movement.
If he's there, it's a good policy.
You can't be moving people all around just because they'd like a house across the street.
But he went ahead and went to bat and finally got authority for us to do that.
So Mimi was happy.
And later on, I was playing golf with the chief of staff at Heidelberg.
We were playing out there one day.
And he was getting ready to tee off.
It was the first time I'd played with him and met him, you know.
And he's almost his back sprint.
He said, wait a minute.
Is your name Andrews?
I said, yeah.
He said, are you Andrews?
And he's sitting on me, moving across the street.
I said, I'm guilty.
I'm in.
He said, you don't know what a flap you caused on me.
He wasn't mad at me at all, but he was just retching on me for who I was.
And I was the one that caused this thing.
And what helped me there, General Sherman, I said, was really another outstanding person.
leader and a gentleman.
He was hopeful to get the 18th Airborne Corps at Fort Bragg, and he didn't land to believe he would after this assignment.
But he got his assignment instead of being Commanding General of the 18th Airborne Corps, he was assigned to Provo Marshal General in Washington.
And there's two reasons.
One is he didn't like the job in particular.
But he said, why put an infantry officer when we have qualified MPs?
I think Maples was an MP, wasn't he, before he became Inspector General?
Well, I don't know either.
It doesn't make any difference.
And he named a BG we had right there in Usarua.
And he thought he was going to get them.
He said, why don't we get them here?
Well, they told him like they do anybody, a general law says to take on it like anybody else.
He said, well, you'll either accept that job or we'll accept your retirement.
He said, okay, I'll retire.
And he retired.
And sure enough, they had a plan that he was going to get the Airbnb.
This was only a temporary job, waiting for somebody else to be released.
So he really outsmarted himself, but he was a man of principle, so he retired.
So I became the commanding officer of 7th Army Support Command, a major general's position as a colonel.
And I commanded it.
Why didn't they send over a major general?
Well, he wasn't available at the time.
He came about three months later, something like that.
So General Bruce Clark was the commanding general of USARUR there in Heidelberg.
And he used to write me letters.
He's a great letter writer.
He'll have a thought during the night.
Another brilliant individual.
And they called him.
They didn't call him back from retirement.
But instead of retirement, they sent him to USARUR, waiting for somebody else.
I don't know what.
military politics was, but he was in it.
But he has thoughts on all sorts of things, and he writes it.
He's a great writer.
So he'd write me letters on the subject.
It could be almost anything.
And it would be addressed, Colonel Theodore H. Andrews, Commanding General of 7th Army Support Command.
So...
At least I got a good official report on that.
Of course, this one was signed by not Bruce Clark, but Gar Davidson, who was the Seventh Army Commander.
And I think that was a big boost.
At this time, well, a couple of years later, the United States was gearing up for Vietnam, and of course,
support in Europe, the supplies in Europe declined.
Did you have any of that decline while you were there from 1960 to 62, or was it two or... Two or...
Still, as far as the Army, or as far as the military is concerned, Europe was sort of the first line of defense.
We were still following the 7th Army Support Command, and we had the responsibility for supervising.
We positioned
two armored division worth of equipment in Europe.
And that was just building up for that.
And then we had an exercise where they exercised one division that got it there.
They brought them over and they took this out of storage and went out on maneuvers on that.
So we were still, at that time, building up equipment.
But I'm sure later on they were drawing down, if they weren't drawing down that, they were drawing down back there in the States in National Guard.
Did you have any relations with the French?
While we were there?
Did you personally deal with any of the French generals or any colonels, any of their officers?
Well, we were invited in the French, as you on the NATO lineup, you've got American zones, the French zone, the German zone, British zone.
I was invited one time as a commander, I guess that's when I was still in the 18th Infantry, to visit a demonstration down in the French zone.
That's about the only time I had.
Now, at the camp near Kaiserslautern, when we first got there, that was run by the French.
It was called French Camp.
But later on, the Americans took it over completely.
No really direct on a day-to-day relationship.
Did you deal with any foreign governments at all, or it was just basically dealing with support, right?
No, basically it was strictly Seventh Army.
And you had no problems as far as getting a proper amount of supplies during this time?
Not at that time.
Now, wait a minute.
I'm going to contradict myself.
The equipment of 7th Army, particularly that which we inherited from the 7th Division, was not near up to the standard of the equipment we had at Fort Ronnie.
The jeep were tired, deferred maintenance.
You've probably heard that if you've talked to generals.
That was the rule of the day.
Anything could be deferred because you didn't have spare parts of money for it.
It would be deferred.
We got some new equipment though.
Front line ambulances, for example, we got some new equipment.
We got a piece of equipment before we left Raleigh, a little self-propelled cannon, which really turned out not to be too good.
So the austerity was there, there's no question about that.
Deferred maintenance on buildings too.
which they still, it's even worse now because they've deferred it, deferred it, deferred it.

You were in Germany during the Russians' building of the Berlin Wall and also during the time that President Kennedy came to Germany and Berlin and made his famous speech that I am a Berliner in 1961.
Do you remember that?
Yeah, I was the 7th Army Support Command.
But by the way, my successor to the 18th Infantry,
He took the 18th Infantry.
That was the unit that went through, you know, to Berlin.
This was a test.
They didn't know whether it was going to be World War III or what it was because the Germans had blockaded Berlin, you know, and had stopped traffic on the Autobahn going to Berlin.
They did let the trains run, continue to run.
So the 18th Infantry went.
to Berlin who was welcomed by Vice President Johnson as he entered Berlin.
But I had no involvement in any of that at all.
OK. Now, on your next assignment as Deputy Chief of Staff,
in Fort McPherson in the Third Army.
Is this one when you were promoted to general?
Yeah.
Tell me.
I was selected.
I got my star.
When you were selected.
Okay, tell me how you found out that you were selected.
Well, this is a...
I had a friend
named Chickalella that was over in Europe at the same time.
He was a G3 of the Corps.
And Chickalella, he's a big operator.
He finally got promoted to major general.
And I think he'd been promoted to brigadier general.
But I was at Fort McClellan, and old Chickalella gave me a call.
He said, say, I just saw the list
of officers that haven't been published yet.
But I saw the list that the board has submitted.

And I'm sure it's routine that they approve, although Chief of Staff hadn't been known to line out one officer one time because of a physical problem that he knew about that apparently nobody else knew about.
But he said, you're on the list.
Of course, I was really elated then because that's a great
Of course, I didn't tell anybody, but I had more sense than that.
That's just like talking about a no-hitter in a game.
You put the hoax on it.
So time went on, and finally the list came out.
In the last little act, my name wasn't on it.
It was not?
Yeah.
So I thought, gee, maybe old Chickalella was mistaken, or maybe for some reason my name was taken off.
Because the chief of staff,

can recommend you know it's approved by the president sure and the president could very well you could recommend that you could eliminate somebody or maybe something had been added the president has been known to add names on the list not somebody else not lately done though because you know they accept because after all that you're going to have a lot of screenings and so i really sweated that out see i guess
Sometimes they carry over to the next year, but usually they don't because they throw it back in and you all do it again in the next committee.
Because each year you've got new people becoming eligible.
And you have others that are dropping off because of the age of them.
But fortunately, that year they had split it into two different parts.
And long in the fall, here comes out the new list with me right at the head of the list.
Chickalilla was right.
I celebrate it.
But the deputy chief of staff job there is, of course, just as the name implies, you assist the chief of staff of the Army in the paperwork.
What was the size of the Third Army and the responsibilities?
Boy, see, it included the...
It included 101st Airborne, 82nd, 18th Airborne Corps, all of the schools were bidding in on the troops.
All of the troops and facilities in the area were headquartered in Atlanta all down south.
The First Army went north up in the
And so it was a lot of activity, a lot of paperwork, a lot of budget problems, maintenance problems.
Sounds like a desk job.
Oh, yeah.
Did you like this job as much as you liked being in Germany commanding the battle group?
Oh, no.
No job compared to that battle group.
Do you think that the battle group job was what you consider the highlight of your career?
Well, my battalion in World War II, I think the 3rd Battalion, because I was with it for quite some time in a lot of different situations.
Those two jobs?
I'd say the 18th was more of a joy because this other was a... You talk about responsibility, you get responsibility for an infantry battalion in combat.
where you can really, that's when a decision or judgment can, you're taking lives or losing lives, or it can be successful.
And that hurts you.
You get close to those people, it's like losing a member of your family.
Fortunately, when you get replacements, you don't know every soldier personally, but it's still a,
You know that every one of those wife, in some cases, mother, father, you know, the whole family.
So when you see that mutilated body, that really shouldn't stay with the unit in combat too long because there is such a thing as battle to take.
Fortunately, I never did get it.
I almost got it one time because in San Pietro in Italy, we were attacking and I was in a depression.
Of course, I got there because that
what little shelter we had was it.
And I was there, and I called in a hunch.
Something said, get up and move.
So I just got up and moved over.
And the artillery liaison officer came up, and he got in the same position.
He just got there in a mortar round, hit him in the back.
He was on his stomach.
And of course, cut him in two.
And while the two separate parts of his body, his head looked up and looked right at me.
And he said something like, I'm here that they got me, or something like that.
Then you start worrying or thinking about, am I having a hunch?
You know, you're inseparable.
And of course you're not.
I don't know what to call that, fate, or I don't know what it was.
But you kind of feel, maybe I'm the one who should.
If I stayed there, I'd say he was going somewhere else.
So I can go through my life from the very beginning and how fortunate I have been in different situations.
So that's what I come back to as far as my career.
I've just been lucky.
Just been lucky.
Now, were you happy to go to Korea?
Well, yes.
Of course, I was so elated to be selected for General Officer, you know, I was ready to go, because now I'm starting out in a... And I had that nice tour in Germany, and of course...
Vietnam War hadn't quite started.
Now, our employment had.
See, Kennedy was influenced, or he was a great supporter of the Green Berets.
You know, their organization where they... Did you have anything to do with that?
No.
The nature of their organization, you know, they go in and they're teams and they organize.
In other words, with a few highly skilled Americans, we can generate, you know, stability or...

combat without getting it and if they can it's a very attractive and so Kennedy thought this is great then maybe we can accomplish what we want to in Vietnam without employing a lot of troops and but just when I got to to Korea and now my assignment was the assistant division commander for combat operations
We were scheduled to have an amphibious operation, which I was given that responsibility as soon as I got there.
So we made our plans, and we reconorded the area where we were going to do it.
And we had the ships identified, of course, the Navy participation, and then the Gulf of Tonkin occurred.
What were your feelings of the Gulf of Tonkin?
Well, of course, that distance I didn't know about, but I learned a lot about it later.
So the Navy, of course, was diverted in.
Everything was towards the result of the Gulf of Tonkin.
So that amphibious was called off.
And so we continued to train.
Then we had a Corps, two US divisions.
Now it's reduced to one.
And good training, because, see, you don't have any dependents.
You don't have anywhere to go.
So you train day and night.
Well, you don't train every night.
But you can concentrate, devote your full attention, which you couldn't do in Europe.
See, they have their families, sick wives.
Hi.
How are you?
Very good, ma'am.
I decided on the omelet.
Would you rather have coffee or tea?
How long were you in Korea?
A little over a year.
The Korean people, I really liked them.
Of course, I had known a little bit about Korea in the month that I was in during the war.
But they were really friendly.
They loved music, children, and flowers.
They liked American stuff.
What did you think about their ability?
They tried to do everything that we do.
Even they designed their military officers.
They redesigned our black uniform and patterned our flight jackets.
I learned, I think, that the women in Korea are second class, you know.
The husband, that's wrong.
Mama-son, she runs everything.
in our maneuvering around, sometimes we have to cross their terrain.
And you're wasting your time if you talk to Papa's son.
If you want to get something done, you can talk to Mama's son.
If he says yes and she hadn't said yes, you're in trouble, you know, couldn't you?
So, like so many cultures in the world, they make you think or let the males think they're running things, but really they don't.
They let them talk big, smoke the pipe.
How did the troops get along with the Korean civilians?
Real well.
What did you think of the fighting ability of their army?
Korean?
Real fighting.
They're fierce fighters.
They're near what the Gurkhas were.
Because the Gurkhas, you know, they, we were talking back in Italy, I'm going way back then, they were great knife fighters.
And they were near us, and it wasn't unusual at all to have them to feel at night the neck.
They're looking to see if you had dog tags.
If you had dog tags, then you were American.
But whoa, be you if you didn't have your dog tags on, because that'd cut your throat or cut off your ears.
Bring ears back to prove that the bodies, I don't mean the Koreans were that brutal and more civilized, I guess.
But they did a tremendous job, and Vietnam's a good example.
In fact, the Vietnamese soon learned to leave them alone
They'd probe and try to find where the Americans were rather than get mixes with those Koreans.
Of course, the Koreans were...
I mentioned the Gurkhas.
The Koreans are kind of brutal.
I mean, they don't show any mercy either.
But in Korea, we had, you know, in our divisions there, we had Koreans in our American divisions.
Each company had a couple, or a few Koreans.
Oh, quite a few, 15 to 20.
It was called the Korean augmentation.
And that presented sort of a problem, because Americans, of course, got paid a lot more.
Sure.
And the Koreans had the same equipment.
But if somebody stole something from a Korean,
you know, like a mess kit or something like that.
He really had a problem.
Plus, he didn't have money to spend in the PX.
Later, we had a Katusa PX, which they would rather have anyway because they don't particularly like the same thing Americans do.
Right.
And they don't particularly like our food either because Koreans like kimchi.
You ever eat kimchi?
I know it's down to here.
H-E-B, they sell it in the store.
What is it?
It's cabbage and fish and garlic and they mix it all together and they put it in a great big stone jar and bury it in the ground.
And I'm telling you, for wintertime.
Do it in summer, of course, when they're harvesting all this stuff.
Oh, it's terrible.
You think somebody's been eating garlic.
It's about the only way to get that rotten fish and garlic and all this other thing.
But they love that.
In fact, I had a
I was up near the DMZ.
I wasn't at the division headquarters.
I was at the DMZ at a real nice general's mess.
The brigade commander was there, and several of the units were up there.
And we had a mess.
We had waiters, Korean waiters that we paid.
And they'd come in in the wintertime to serve.
And his accent was so strong, you'd pick up a piece of bread and it even tastes like that odor, you know.
So we finally got these characters.
We said, please, this is our mess.
We're paying you.
Please don't eat kimchi.
Well, yes, sir.
We agreed.
They'd go for about two or three days, and then they couldn't resist coming back again.

Recently, in the last couple of years, President Carter was considering decreasing the number of troops in Korea, and there was a lot of statements that that would weaken our posture, and we shouldn't do it, and we should maintain our 50-some thousand troops that we have in Korea.
What's your opinion?
Should we have that many troops there, or do you think that we should bring some home?
What do you think?

Well, of course, I think it should have stayed just like it was when we were there for stability and also to protect nuclear weapons that we might have or might in the future have, that sort of thing.
We control the Koreans.
I should say we didn't exactly control them.
We might have tried to.
But we had a stabilizing effect on keeping the South Koreans from attacking the North Koreans.
Because when they got strong and got the equipment and so forth, they wanted to go unify their country.
And of course, the North Koreans feel the same way, at least Kim, the commander.
And it's good training if you're going to maintain the division.
Now, you're going to say, now, I know what you're doing.
That shows you have a military man in the unit.
We know that if we move back a division to the United States, the chances are that it's going to be deactivated.
You're just going to have one less division.
We need that division.
Japan's not strong.
And it's good because MacArthur's Constitution, they can only have a defense force, and they say we have a defense force.
We can't use anything offensively.
Actually, they really don't have sufficient strength for a defense force.
And they're very, Korea's very important to them.
And they're not going to do it.
In fact,
A few years ago, we would be horrified if we even thought that they were going to move something there, because they see expansion, there they go again, imperialistic.
And it's good training, and to have the forces there.
And it's stabilized.
Now the main thing, though, Carter, as far as I'm concerned, was a disaster from the word go, although I wanted a southerner to be successful, see.
But it was a disaster.
So many things he did.
If he had negotiated, used that as a negotiating, you know, with the North Koreans, for example, or to use it somewhere as a chip for negotiating.
But he just unilaterally said, I'm going to take these out.
Same thing with the B-1.
If you'd use that as a negotiating to reduce, or the neutron weapon, for example.
Unilaterally, after convincing the Germans finally to accept that as a very fine weapon for defense without decimating their country, see?
Unilaterally, Smith read about it in the paper.
After he had gone to the people and stuck his neck out, which was unpopular, and now it's really unpopular now, with the Germans, particularly the German youth,
I'm not the neutron, but any kind of weapon now, even updating what we already have in missile.
So I thought it was a mistake then.
I don't say we shouldn't take them out someday.
But see, I lived through the other.
When the Secretary of State announced to the world that our security line
It was Japan, Taiwan, Philippines, Okinawa, and on around.
Eliminated Korea.
And then what happened?
And if you said that, then we phased out our troops.
Now, North Koreans look and said, well, they invited us.
They said, this isn't vital to the security of the United States.
So now's the time to move in.
So they attacked, and what happened?
Harry Truman managed to declare not an emergency, not a war, but a police action.
And then we found we were in a full-blown war with no troops prepared, no equipment.
The units we had in Japan at that time not only were understrength and under-equipped, they weren't even...
Some had a phantom, a ghost,
regiment because division had two regiments under strength.
Air Force wasn't ready at all.
Neither was the Navy.
And all at once we found that we were in a war.
And so we know what happened.
We put in and we were in a battle and finally got kicked around all the way down to the perimeter.
and fought back with all those casualties.
Of course, those casualties didn't seem so large now since we had Vietnam all these years.
That's another question.
When you were in Korea, did the Gulf of Tonkin and then the subsequent buildup in Vietnam have any impact on your maneuvers, your training, your efficiency in Korea?
Because there, just like in Germany, we're supposed to be combat ready to fight.
It can't even be an alert there because the DMZ, where we were sitting, we were up to see the DMZ.
And we had troops actually on the DMZ.
1st Cavalry Division had troops on the DMZ.
We don't any longer.
We go back where we don't man.
And the Koreans manned on the DMZ since we lost one division.
No.
We were always on alert, see, and we had practice alert, just like we had in Europe.
It was easier there because we didn't have people out living with their families in apartments, you know, 15, 20 miles away.
All you had to do was wake the people up and get in the vehicles and move to dispersal area.
After that, from 65 to 68, you had a, to me, it looks like a very important job in the Pentagon.
Oh, yeah.
That was in the National Military Command Center.
As Deputy Director of Operations and later Chief of Far Eastern Division Plans and Policy.
Yeah.
All in the Joint Staff.
Thinking about a pressure job now.
That National Military Command Center.
Because you're actually the duty officer of the world.
and certainly the duty officer of the United States, because all of the elements of government look to this military command post to answer questions, because we have the facility to do that.
What happens anywhere in the world?
So basically what you're doing in the National Military Command Center is information?
Command and control of all the armed forces.
U.S. and deployed overseas.
And I'll describe, it's in the Pentagon, in the Joint Staff's area.
And of course you have to have special clearance and a special path to get in.
Because then you don't have this, or sometimes you have VIPs that they take in, and the Goldwater and a few like that come in.
But you have a brigadier general or a flag officer on duty 24 hours a day.
And, of course, we have Air Force Navy admins in the Army.
And you have an assistant that sits there with you.
I say sit because it's a big room, almost as big as a football field, but not quite.
It's almost an issue.
configured almost like that.
And we're up here with all of our telephones.
And out on the floor, you have representatives of the CIA, the State Department, Defense Intelligence, USIA, and area specialists, which could be manned by Army, Navy, Air Force.
It doesn't make any difference.
So that every part of the world, you have an individual who is monitoring on an hour-to-hour basis, day-to-day, what the situation is there, what we have.
In the case of the Navy, they can answer where all of the ships are.
They monitor all of the ships worldwide.
The Persian government, any time, they can tell you what it is.
I'm sorry to interrupt, but I'm starting to... Shall we continue?
Yeah, one thing that I failed to say about Korea that had an effect on my career was that I had developed a back problem, a herniated disc.
I don't know what caused it.
It just happened.
Spinal disc?
Yeah.
And so I spent considerable time, about three weeks, in the hospital.
And it results with that physical problem.
In Korea?
You were in the hospital in Korea?
Yeah.
If I was in the States, I'd probably go to Walton Reed where they had the surgery, but I wanted to finish my tour in Korea because this happened halfway through the tour.
So I continued on, but I had to get out of the hospital, but not up to really the efficiency you expect someone to do.
And there's no question that affected my career from then on because I always had this problem that you lift anything or run, pain comes back, still does.
Of course, I've learned now there's no reason for exertion.
Well, John, we'll get back to the military command center.
And you were telling me about the functions and duties there.
Right.

If you visualize all of these people and with their knowledge and their accessibility to, because they themselves continually got updated, I don't mean every second, but they were sure that from their sources, and the Army has an operations center, the Navy does, and the Air Force, but this was, and we were all tied into them, so we were fed information from everyone.
The key part, however, to the facility was the communication we had.
And it was off to the side.
And we could speak directly to any command element in the world where we had U.S. And each day we would test that command.
We'd actually come home with a conference call, the flag officer.
would go in in the communication because the outside was local communications type of thing.
But this was the powerful communication.
And they didn't even, communication even had a capability.
If you had a weak signal, they could raise the volume on that signal.
Would it be by satellite?
Yeah, they used satellite, the whole range of communication.
And we also have
an airborne command post, and a Navy command post.
So we would bring them in this community check, communication check with the others.
We'd go to use the .
I'll say every place that we had a command.
I don't mean down a lower level, but we had the capability of doing that.
For example, we had a
The bomb says, let's see, we had a month or two which there was no bombing in North Vietnam.
But the situation was such that the decision had been made to resume bombing.
Secretary of State called, I happened to be on duty,
And he says, this is very important.
I want to know when the first bomb drops in the resumption of bombing in North Vietnam.
Now, he pointed out this is important because we have pre-positioned messages at all of our embassies in the world.
And I don't want to prematurely release this for weather conditions or reason, you know, that we really can't execute the mission.
Can you let me know immediately?
And I said, yes, sir.
So all we did was go through the sink back with this powerful communication, went on into the carriers were going to make the first strike.
To them, I talked to the, it wasn't a captain, it was an officer on, I guess a man in their community, their duty officer on the carrier, and explained what our situation was and can you let me know
when the first bomb is dropped.
No abortion or anything like that the first time.
He said, absolutely.
He says, I'll patch in right now to the flight commander.
And you will hear him tell me when he has dropped, when the bomb's away.
So here I am monitoring with the clock ticking along.
So pretty soon you heard.
Of course, I was a little bit weaker because he was coming from the radio.
And he says, bombs away.
So immediately it called up the State Department.
It was just a matter of, well, almost simultaneously.
We had in Washington the word.
Now you don't like to do that because you tie up a lot of communication.
You like to deal only with the headquarters rather than go on down.
But you just heard the fighter pilot just say, bombs away.
Yeah, he gave a...
The word, it might have been other words at that time, but anyway, whatever he said, the indication.
Right at that second, you got on the phone and called the State Department.
Yeah, exactly.
So the Secretary of State knew about that almost simultaneously, just a few minutes.
That's just an example of the communication, how it worked.
That's fantastic.
Now, you get involved with a lot of things.
On the desk of the flag officer is a red telephone.
That's directly to the president from the White House.
And whenever that red light comes on, flashes, it actually flashes.
Of course, you also hear a signal.
When you pick that up, there's no secretary on there.
It's the president himself.
And usually he calls.
This was LBJ.
He'd call about 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning.
Some said perhaps he had a bladder problem, but he slept very little.
And he had, he monitored all of television, CBS, NBC, all of them at the same time, plus radio.
And if a news flash came over about a strike in Vietnam, say they had heavy casualties, several planes were lost, these are just news reports, he'd be on that line asking
He wanted an update, because I just heard that.
Can you tell me about it?
Well, while you're talking, of course, we have all the information we have that my assistant, who's also, he's on the line, and he signals the individual whose area we're talking about.
Of course, it's always Vietnam.
So he ran up with a map, put it up in front, and he was handing information while we were talking to the president, trying to answer his questions.
Of course, oftentimes we didn't have it, so we just had to tell you, well, Mr. President, we don't have an update on that.
I'll notify your situation room just as soon as we have it.
And he said, all right, thank you.
White House has a situation room, too, where they monitor these things.
And often he called them, but he finally got word that they didn't know because they'd have to get the information from us.
So they, too, were always asking us, please update us on this, because they anticipated he might come.
His son-in-law was up near Khe Sanh.
And he was very anxious about a situation up there.
He didn't say, I don't wonder if my son-in-law was there.
Obviously, what was happening?
I shouldn't even say that, because he was interested in every single thing.
It really hurt him to have a report that a pilot had been lost.
It really hurt LBJ.
Yeah.
He wanted to say any chance to find that pilot.
Of course, you can't answer that, I mean, here.
And you don't go back like I've said and try to find out the unit.
Sure.
But it's a normal routine.
But when his son-in-law was over in Vietnam, he was on the phone more often asking about the area?
No, he seemed to call now.
While I was on duty, I guess he called me four times.
And I guess the other flag also on duty, probably about the same area.
That's over a period of a year that I was there.
So he didn't call every night.
But it was always, the call was generated by something that he had just seen or heard on the radio or television, particularly at night.
And some said it wasn't a bladder problem, but he just couldn't sleep.
Didn't only need two or three hours of sleep.
And he wanted to talk to somebody.
Sometimes in the daytime, they'd say, get me that general on the phone.
And they meant that general in the National Military Command Center.
But he sure took a personal interest and suffered with all those guys, so they can't.
Of course, he was under great pressure to recall, you know, yelling at him, LBJ, how many did you kill today?
Another example of a domestic problem that we were confronted with
I don't know whether you remember or not, but we had this massive blackout in the northeastern part of the United States.
Do you remember that?
No.
And so I got a call from, it wasn't the governor of New York, because apparently he wasn't there.
I guess he was Rockefeller at the time, but the lieutenant governor.
And I forget his name.
It was an Italian name.
He says, uh, everybody thought, you know, eventually, or momentarily, they'd get this corrected.

But what bothered, for example, the Lieutenant Governor, it wasn't just a blackout in New York City, it went all the way upstate and in Connecticut and all the way, of course, because it eventually found out it was in the Niagara Falls areas where the problem was.
But he was asking for help.
He said, we need New York City particularly.
Is there something that could be done?
And he had already called, apparently, Secretary McNamara.
McNamara called me a few minutes later and said, say, these people in New York City need some help.
And I said, yes.
I just had a call from the lieutenant governor asking for help.
And he says, uh.
What about the ships in New York Harbor?
Why can't they generate electricity?
One of the problems is they didn't have electricity in New York City to start their auxiliary generator, the power to start the auxiliary generator.
That's really one of the problems.
